Ox and Donkey 
 Melese Getahun Wolde and
 Elizabeth Laird
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A por farmer had an old ox that didn't 
 like to work. 
 
 
 The ox didn't want to plough the farmer's 
 field. 
 
 
 He wanted to stay at home and eat 
 gras, drink water and rest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The farmer had a donkey, to. 
 
 The donkey and the ox were friends.
 At the end of the day, the ox and the
 donkey talked to each other. 
 
 "I'm so tired," the ox said. "I worked hard
 al day. The plough is big and heavy. The
 
 farmer never lets me rest." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The donkey loked at the ox. 
 "The ox is lazy," he thought. "He doesn't 
 
 like to work." 
 
 "Do you think your plough is heavy?" he 
 
 cried. "Believe me, my friend, it is light! I 
 was carying a sack of tef on my back 
 
 today. It was heavier than your plough, I 
 am sure." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day, the two animals met again.
 "I had a bad day today," the ox said. "My
 master's field is far away, and it was ful
 
 of stones. I worked hard al day. I didn't
 have any rest." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "You worked hard?" said the donkey. "I 
 
 went to the market today. It was in the 
 town, many kilometres away. I'm sure I 
 worked harder than you." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day, the ox came home late
 again. 
 
 "Oh, my friend," he said to the donkey.
 "Today was a very bad day for me."
 But the donkey didn't want to listen to the
 
 ox any more. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "You're always tired," he said. "Every day
 is a bad day for you. Listen, I have a god
 
 idea. Tomorow, when the farmer comes,
 lie down on the ground. Close your eyes,
 and say, ‘Mo! Mo!’ The farmer wil
 
 think that you are il. He wil let you rest."
 The ox liked the donkey's idea. "Thank
 
 you, dear donkey, that's a very god idea,"
 he said. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So the next morning, the ox lay down on 
 
 the ground. When the farmer came, the 
 ox closed his eyes. 
 "Mo! Mo!" he said. 
 
 
 The farmer loked at him. 
 "My por old ox is sick," he said. "But I 
 
 must plough my field. Who wil help me? 
 Why, there is my donkey! He can pul the 
 
 plough today." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The farmer tok the donkey out to his
 field. He tied the plough to the donkey,
 and began to hit him with his whip.
 
 "Go on! Faster! Pul!" he caled out to the
 donkey. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The donkey worked hard al day, and in 
 
 the evening he was very tired. 
 
 
 Slowly, he walked home. 
 
 The ox was waiting for him. 
 
 "Dear donkey," the ox said. "I had a lovely 
 day today. I ate some gras, drank some 
 
 water and I rested under a big tre. I 
 want to rest again tomorow. What shal I 
 do? Give me another idea." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The donkey loked at the ox. 
 
 "His work is much worse than mine," he
 thought. "I don't want to do it again
 
 tomorow." 
 
 "My friend," he said at last. "You must be
 
 careful. The farmer was talking to his
 wife today. I heard him saying 'My ox is
 
 always tired and now he is sick. If he is
 not beter tomorow, I wil kil him, and
 we can eat the meat.'" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The ox was very frightened. 
 
 "What? Did he say that?" he cried. "Then I 
 wil work tomorow. I fel quite beter 
 now. I'm not tired at al!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12
